thread.title: Roundup (Oct. 24): Loyola Blakefield football surges past St. Frances, 31-13
thread.title_full: Roundup (Oct. 24): Loyola Blakefield football surges past St. Frances, 31-13

title: Roundup (Oct. 24): Loyola Blakefield football surges past St. Frances, 31-13
text:
Roundup (Oct. 24): Loyola Blakefield football surges past St. Frances, 30-13 Loyola football Steve Ruark / Baltimore Sun 
Loyola wide receivers Matt Bell, second from left, Dana Young, third from left, and Nate Leishear, fourth from left, celebrate Leishear's long reception as Gilman safety Drew Ehrlich, left, looks back in the first quarter of a high school football game in Towson on Friday, Sept. 25, 2015. 
Loyola wide receivers Matt Bell, second from left, Dana Young, third from left, and Nate Leishear, fourth from left, celebrate Leishear's long reception as Gilman safety Drew Ehrlich, left, looks back in the first quarter of a high school football game in Towson on Friday, Sept. 25, 2015. (Steve Ruark / Baltimore Sun) The Loyola Blakefield football team got its first win over St. Frances in two years. 
The Loyola Blakefield football team got its first win over St. Frances in two years. 
The host Dons (4-4, 1-3 Maryland Interscholastic Athletic Association A Conference) scored three touchdowns in the second half to earn a 30-13 victory over the Panthers (1-8, 0-5) on Saturday. The victory ended a three-game losing streak. 
Coach Brant Hall said the opening second-half drive was the key to the win. Loyola went 80 yards, capped by a 2-yard touchdown run by Azende Smith for a 16-7 lead. 
St. Frances "scored the last touchdown of the first half with 1:30 left," Hall said. "When we scored on the first drive of the second half, it changed the momentum of the game." 
Archbishop Curley 28, St. Paul's 3: Rodney Petitt caught a 70-yard touchdown pass in the first quarter to lead the host Friars (5-2, 4-1 MIAA A Conference) past the Crusaders (2-5, 0-5).
